Embassy of Japan hires one more — Looser leaves McGuireWoods Consulting — Chaffetz aide to Larson Communications

With Cate Martel and Matt Yurus

FARA UPDATE — EMBASSY OF JAPAN HIRES ONE MORE: The Embassy of Japan has hired Annapolis, Md.-based Greenfield & Kress to provide “advice and assistance in connection with the normal business of the Japanese Embassy (or Consulate) and other matters as required, as well as information of relevance,” according to documents filed under the Foreign Agents Registration Act.

Brown, who was selected by an AIP executive search committee and unanimously approved by the group’s board, previously served as the chief sensor scientist at the Advanced Technology Center of Rockwell Collins, Inc. and worked concurrently as an adjunct full professor in the Beckman Laser Institute & Medical Clinic of the University of California, Irvine, and in UC Irvine's Department of Computer Science.

CHAFFETZ AIDE TO LARSON COMMUNICATIONS: Melissa Subbotin Sillin, director of media relations for the House Oversight & Government Reform Committee, is moving to San Francisco to work for Larson Communications, where she will be working on strategic communications “to advance educational opportunities and student achievement across the U.S.,” Sillin told friends and colleagues in an email.

NEW COALITION HOSTS LAUNCH HAPPY HOUR: Re:Create — a new coalition that includes the American Library Association, Association of Research Libraries, Center for Democracy and Technology, Computer and Communications Industry Association and Consumer Electronics Association — hosted Thursday evening a happy hour that was attended by members, hill staffers and downtowners.

Spotted at the event were: Reps. Jared Polis and Ruben Gallego; Michael Petricone and Michael Hayes from CEA; Adam Eisgrau, Carrie Russell and Alan Inouye from American Library Association; Julian Leuthold from Geoskope; Nika Nour from the Internet Association; Troy Stock and Mike Flynn from the House Information Technology subcommittee and many more.

ELSEWHERE IN THE INFLUENCE WORLD:

CREDIT CARDS AND CASINOS: Steve Tetreault of the Las Vegas Review-Journal reports that the Defense Department is considering banning credit cards at casinos, but the gaming industry’s chief lobbyist warned against the potential restriction, calling it an overreaction to an audit.

Spotted at the lunch: Anne MacMillan of Roll Global, Autumn Veazey Price of Land O Lakes, Dana Brooks of Elanco, Julie Barkemeyer of NRECA, Hillary Fabrico of the U.S. Sugar Beet Association, Bev Paul of the American Soybean Association and Leslee Oden of the National Turkey Federation.

REVOLVING DOOR STILL SWINGING: According to the Center for Responsive Politics, 42 of the 75 Congress members who left Capitol Hill at the end of the last Congress or during that period are employed — with 18 of them at lobbying firms.

MORNING AG THEFT — WOMEN IN FOOD/AG RAISE MONEY FOR STABENOW: A newly minted "Women in Food and Agriculture" group gathered 25 women Thursday to host its first fundraiser for Senate Agriculture Committee ranking member Debbie Stabenow at Johnny's Half Shell.

RETAIL EXECUTIVES IN TOWN: The National Retail Federation hosted dozens of retail industry leaders this week from companies including Belk, BJ’s Wholesale Club, Ethan Allen, HSNi, Macy’s, The Container Store, Tractor Supply Company and Wal-Mart.

MORNING CYBERSECURITY THEFT — RISHIKOF TO CROWELL & MORING: Harvey Rishikof has joined Crowell & Moring as a senior counsel in the firm's privacy firm's privacy and cybersecurity practice and government contracts group.

PARTY ALERT — ‘SNAPPY HOUR’ NEXT WEEK: After making some key recent hires, Snapchat will host a “Snappy Hour” June 4 to celebrate the launch of the company’s “first Capitol Hill Live Story,” according to an invitation.
